messages.content:
why is my "marp" only doing the first slide - this is my marp md file: ---
marp: true
theme: default
paginate: true
---

<!-- 
# Slide 1
Facilitator Note:
- Welcome participants formally in Arabic
- Introduce yourself and the BEIT/ITC program
- Ask participants to briefly share their name and background
- Explain the program's goal: practical solar skills for jobs and business
-->

# Solar Energy System Design & Installation
## BEIT/ITC Training Program - Mosul

![bg right:40%](https://via.placeholder.com/500x500?text=Solar+Panel+Image)

- 6-Day Intensive Training
- Practical Skills for Real Jobs
- Design → Install → Business

---

<!-- 
# Slide 2
Facilitator Note:
- Show the map of outages
- Ask: "Who experienced a power outage yesterday?" (raise hands)
- Note that most homes in Mosul face 16+ hours of weekly outages
- Emphasize both the problem (energy gap) and opportunity (jobs)
-->

# Iraq's Energy Gap & Jobs

- Average outages in Mosul: **16+ hours/week**
- Diesel generator cost: **250 IQD/kWh**
- Solar industry potential: **50,000+ new jobs by 2030**

![bg right:30%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=Outage+Map)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 3
Facilitator Note:
- Draw a simple bar chart on board showing costs over 5 years
- Calculate a simple example: 250 IQD × 5 kWh × 365 days = yearly diesel cost
- Emphasize that diesel costs RISE while solar is one-time with minimal maintenance
- This is your first chance to introduce ROI concept simply
-->

# Solar vs Diesel: 5-Year Comparison

- Diesel costs **rise yearly** (+8%)
- Solar is **one-time investment** with minimal maintenance
- Break-even point:
  - Homes: < 3 years
  - Clinics: < 1.5 years
  - After break-even: **profit**

---

<!-- 
# Slide 4
Facilitator Note:
- Hold up two physical samples: PV panel and solar thermal tube (if available)
- Ask participants to identify each and explain differences
- Many customers confuse these technologies - engineers must explain clearly
- Emphasize that this training focuses on PV (electricity) not thermal (heat)
-->

# PV vs Thermal: Different Solar Technologies

- **PV (كهروضوئية)**: Converts sunlight to electricity
  - Powers appliances, lights, AC, etc.
  - Scalable from 100W to many MW

- **Thermal (حرارية)**: Heats water or air only
  - No electricity production
  - Not covered in this training

---

<!-- 
# Slide 5
Facilitator Note:
- Draw three simple diagrams on flipchart showing different configurations
- Ask group to discuss which system would be best for: rural clinic, urban apartment
- Highlight that off-grid is more complex but provides energy independence
- Note that hybrid is most common in Mosul due to unreliable grid
-->

# System Types: Off-Grid, On-Grid, Hybrid

- **Off-Grid**: Complete independence
  - Batteries required
  - No connection to utility grid

- **On-Grid**: Grid-connected
  - No batteries (usually)
  - Requires stable grid

- **Hybrid**: Best of both
  - Batteries + grid connection
  - Most popular in Mosul

---

<!-- 
# Slide 6
Facilitator Note:
- Show PVGIS map screenshot and point to Mosul
- Hand out PSH reference tables for different Iraqi cities
- Have participants circle their hometown's PSH value for later sizing activity
- Explain why tilt matters and demonstrate with a panel or notebook
-->

# Iraq's Solar Resource: Peak Sun Hours

- Mosul: **~5 PSH/day**
- Basra: **~5.6 PSH/day**
- Baghdad: **~5.3 PSH/day**

**Optimal tilt** = Latitude – 10°
For Mosul: **26° tilt** for fixed panels

![bg right:30%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=PSH+Map)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 7
Facilitator Note:
- Pass around an actual module or cutaway sample
- Ask participants to identify each component as you point to it
- Explain how EVA protects cells and importance of junction box being waterproof
- Connect to quality inspection later - what to look for in good panels
-->

# PV Module Anatomy

- **Front cover**: Tempered low-iron glass
- **Encapsulant**: EVA protects cells
- **Solar cells**: Mono or polycrystalline silicon
- **Backsheet**: Weather protection
- **Frame**: Aluminum for mounting
- **Junction box**: Contains bypass diodes (IP67)

![bg right:40%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=Panel+Cross-Section)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 8
Facilitator Note:
- Show actual inverter if available, pointing out terminals
- Explain MPPT in simple terms (finds best voltage/current combination)
- Highlight the importance of warranty - should be minimum 5 years
- Mention that sizing the inverter correctly is crucial (Day 2 topic)
-->

# Inverters: Heart of the System

- **Main functions**:
  - DC to AC conversion
  - Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT)
  - System monitoring & protection

- **Types**:
  - String inverters (most common)
  - Hybrid inverters (with battery)
  - Microinverters (one per panel)

- **Key specs**: Capacity, efficiency, warranty

---

<!-- 
# Slide 9
Facilitator Note:
- Show cost-per-cycle bar chart comparing both technologies
- Discuss the higher upfront cost but better lifetime value of Li-ion
- Mention importance of ventilation, especially in Mosul's hot climate
- If possible, show a small battery sample from each type
-->

# Battery Comparison: Li-ion vs Lead-Acid

|  | Lithium-Ion | Lead-Acid |
|--|-------------|-----------|
| Cycles | 6,000 @80% DoD | 1,000 @50% DoD |
| Size/Weight | Smaller & lighter | Larger & heavier |
| Initial Cost | Higher | Lower |
| Lifetime Cost | **Lower** per kWh-cycle | Higher |
| Maintenance | Minimal | Regular |
| Best for | Long-term investment | Budget systems |

---

<!-- 
# Slide 10
Facilitator Note:
- Walk through the load calculation for one appliance (e.g., fan)
- Have participants calculate the second line on their calculators
- Emphasize accuracy in hours of use (underestimation is common)
- This table matches the site survey form they'll use in the field
-->

# Load Calculation Example: Typical Mosul Home

| Appliance | Power (W) | Quantity | Hours/day | Daily kWh |
|-----------|-----------|----------|-----------|-----------|
| Fans | 95 | 2 | 7 | 1.33 |
| TV | 60 | 1 | 5 | 0.30 |
| Refrigerator | 150 | 1 | 24 | 3.60 |
| Lights | 15 | 6 | 5 | 0.45 |
| **TOTAL** | | | | **5.68** |

Formula: W × Qty × Hours ÷ 1000 = kWh

---

<!-- 
# Slide 11
Facilitator Note:
- Demonstrate clinometer app on your phone (against a straight edge)
- Explain the site survey workflow in sequence
- Emphasize safety when accessing roofs (proper footwear, buddy system)
- This slide transitions to the field-walk activity that follows
-->

# Site Survey Steps

1. **Safe roof access** & initial inspection
2. **Measure roof tilt** with clinometer
3. **Identify obstacles** that could cause shading
4. **Document dimensions** of usable roof area
5. **Examine electrical setup** (breaker size, wiring)
6. **Interview homeowner** about energy needs

---

<!-- 
# Slide 12
Facilitator Note:
- Demonstrate how to mark obstacles on horizon sketch
- Show Sun-Path app on phone and how the overlay works
- Have participants practice during the upcoming activity
- Explain the goal: identify shading that could reduce output
-->

# Horizon Sketch: Capturing Shade Obstacles

- Mark obstacles in all directions (N-E-S-W)
- Measure height angle using **hand-span method**
  - Arm's length, each fist = ~10°
- Use Sun-Path overlay to estimate shading impact
- Goal: Shading loss **<15%** of annual production

![bg right:40%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=Horizon+Sketch)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 13
Facilitator Note:
- This is our first financial slide - make it simple but compelling
- Show the formula for monthly savings (diesel cost - solar cost)
- Emphasize this is what customers care about most: saving money
- Transition to Day 2 where we'll calculate exact numbers
-->

# ROI Basics: Making the Business Case

- **Initial investment** (one-time): System cost
- **Monthly savings**: Diesel cost reduced/eliminated
- **Break-even point**: When savings = initial cost
- **Profit period**: Everything after break-even
- **Financial metrics**: Simple payback, IRR, NPV

**Example:** 5.68 kWh/day × 250 IQD/kWh × 30 days = 
**42,600 IQD monthly savings**

---

<!-- 
# Slide 14
Facilitator Note:
- This slide begins Day 2
- Walk through each step of the calculation process
- Work through an example using 5.68 kWh from previous day
- Have participants calculate along with you using calculators
-->

# System Sizing: Step-by-Step Process

1. Daily energy need: **5.68 kWh**
2. Add system losses (×1.2): **6.82 kWh**
3. Divide by Peak Sun Hours (5 for Mosul): **1,364 Wp**
4. Select panel size (e.g., 410W): **4 panels**
   (1,640W actual array size)
5. Battery sizing: 
   6.82 kWh × 2 days ÷ 0.8 DoD = **17.05 kWh**

---

<!-- 
# Slide 15
Facilitator Note:
- Open the IRR calculation spreadsheet (Google Sheet)
- Demonstrate changing variables (panel quantity, battery size)
- Highlight the IRR percentage changing in real-time
- Explain that higher IRR = better investment (target >15%)
-->

# Financial Analysis: IRR Calculator

- **IRR** = Internal Rate of Return (investment quality)
- **Blue cells** can be changed:
  - Panel quantity
  - Battery capacity
  - System cost
- **Target**: IRR **≥15%** or payback **≤5 years**
- Practice with different scenarios

![bg right:40%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=IRR+Calculator+Screenshot)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 16
Facilitator Note:
- Show PVWatts website (or screenshot if no internet)
- Walk through entering Mosul location, system size, tilt
- Emphasize these are optional tools - hand calculations still needed
- Download sample results to reference during sizing exercise
-->

# Digital Tools: PVWatts & Viktor

**PVWatts**:
- Estimates annual energy production
- Accounts for location, system details
- Shows month-by-month output

**Viktor**:
- Visual roof layout tool
- Helps optimize panel arrangement
- Calculates shade impact

**Remember**: Tools help, but understanding the calculations is essential.

---

<!-- 
# Slide 17
Facilitator Note:
- This is more advanced - keep it brief but informative
- Show cross-section diagram of PERC technology
- If available, pass around half-cut cell sample
- Emphasize the efficiency gain may justify higher price
-->

# Advanced Module Technology

**PERC Cells**:
- Passivated Emitter Rear Cell
- **+2% efficiency** via rear passivation
- Standard in newer modules

**Half-Cut Cells**:
- Reduces resistive losses by **~75%**
- Better shade tolerance
- Increases power output **~5W**

**Cost impact**: +6-10% for advanced tech

---

<!-- 
# Slide 18
Facilitator Note:
- If available, have a bifacial panel to demonstrate
- Shine flashlight on rear to show cells generating
- Explain limited use cases in residential (need bright surface below)
- Mention schools and carports as good applications
-->

# Bifacial Panels: Double-Sided Generation

- Generate power from **both sides**
- Rear side captures reflected light
- Potential gain: **+10-25%** output

**Requirements for good performance**:
- High-reflectivity surface below (white, light concrete)
- Elevated mounting (≥20cm clearance)
- Proper tilt angle

**Best for**: Schools, carports, ground mounts

---

<!-- 
# Slide 19
Facilitator Note:
- Distribute actual specification sheets for 2 panels and 2 inverters
- Have participants fill in the comparison matrix worksheet
- Walk around to assist with finding values on spec sheets
- Discuss results as a group - which combination is best for what scenarios
-->

# Choosing Components: Spec Sheet Comparison

Key specifications to compare:

**Solar Panels**:
- Wattage, efficiency, temperature coefficient
- Warranty terms, dimensions, weight

**Inverters**:
- Capacity, efficiency, MPPT voltage range
- Grid integration features, monitoring
- Warranty period, support availability

**Batteries**:
- Capacity, DoD, cycle life, chemistry
- Weight, dimensions, warranty

---

<!-- 
# Slide 20
Facilitator Note:
- Explain LCOE simply: total cost divided by total energy
- Show why cycle life matters so much for batteries
- Connect to the BoQ exercise later today
- Emphasize comparing LCOE to diesel cost (250 IQD/kWh)
-->

# LCOE: Comparing Lifetime Energy Costs

**Levelized Cost of Energy**:
- Total system cost ÷ Lifetime energy production
- Measured in IQD/kWh
- Allows comparison with diesel, grid

**Example components**:
- PV panels: 5-8 IQD/kWh (25 year life)
- Inverters: 15-20 IQD/kWh (10 year life)
- Li-ion: 40-45 IQD/kWh (6000 cycles)
- Lead-acid: 80-90 IQD/kWh (1000 cycles)

**Target**: System LCOE **<110 IQD/kWh**

---

<!-- 
# Slide 21
Facilitator Note:
- Show two quotations - one complete, one with hidden fees
- Have groups highlight suspicious items or missing information
- Discuss common hidden fees in the Iraqi market
- Emphasize the importance of clear, detailed quotations
-->

# Supplier Quotation Review: Finding Hidden Costs

**Watch for these common hidden charges**:
- Shipping & customs fees (adds ~12%)
- Warranty shipping costs
- Installation "extras"
- Equipment substitutions
- Undefined "administrative fees"

**Red flags on quotations**:
- Missing unit prices
- Vague specifications
- Unrealistic timelines
- No warranty details

---

<!-- 
# Slide 22
Facilitator Note:
- Use actual MC4 connectors to demonstrate
- Draw the two wiring types on the board
- Measure voltage with multimeter if equipment available
- Emphasize safety when working with high DC voltages
-->

# Wiring Fundamentals: Series vs Parallel

**Series Connection**:
- Voltage adds, current stays the same
- Connect + to - between panels
- Typical for strings to inverter

**Parallel Connection**:
- Current adds, voltage stays the same
- Connect + to +, - to -
- Used when adding strings

**Key rule**: String Voc must stay below inverter maximum
(Example: 40V × 12 panels = 480V < 600V maximum)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 23
Facilitator Note:
- Pass around actual protection devices if available
- Demonstrate proper mounting positions on diagram
- Explain each device's purpose simply
- Connect to safety and code compliance
-->

# Protection Devices: System Safety

**Essential protection components**:
- **DC Isolator**: Located within 1m of array
- **Fuses/MCB**: Rated at 1.25 × string Isc
- **Surge Protection Device (SPD)**: At combiner & AC box
- **Residual Current Device (RCD)**: Personal protection
- **AC Circuit Breaker**: Sized to inverter output

**Remember**: 
- Proper protection = safer system
- Proper protection = longer system life

---

<!-- 
# Slide 24
Facilitator Note:
- This begins Day 4 content on installation
- Show the flowchart or draw on board
- Walk through the sequence step-by-step
- Emphasize that tomorrow's practical will follow this exact sequence
-->

# Installation Workflow: 4-Step Process

1. **Preparation & Safety** (30%)
   - Site verification, tool check, safety briefing

2. **Mounting System** (20%)
   - Rail installation, panel mounting, torque check

3. **Electrical Works** (40%)
   - DC wiring, inverter mounting, AC connection

4. **Pre-Commissioning** (10%)
   - Visual check, polarity test, system inspection

![bg right:30%](https://via.placeholder.com/400x400?text=Installation+Workflow)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 25
Facilitator Note:
- Distribute the IEC code handout (Arabic preferred)
- Point out key color codes and explain why standardization matters
- Show actual wire samples with correct colors if available
- Relate to inspection process - what code violations to watch for
-->

# IEC-Iraq Safety Codes

**Wire Color Codes**:
- Live/Phase: **Brown**
- Neutral: **Blue**
- Earth/Ground: **Yellow-Green**
- DC+: **Red**
- DC-: **Black**

**Key Requirements**:
- DC isolator within **1m** of array
- PV cable rating minimum **90°C**
- Earthing/grounding resistance **<10Ω**
- Professional labeling of all components

---

<!-- 
# Slide 26
Facilitator Note:
- Show actual torque wrench and demonstrate setting and use
- Fill out first line of the log sheet as an example
- Explain why proper torque is critical (loose connections = fire risk)
- Connect to quality assurance and professional standards
-->

# Quality Assurance: Torque Log Documentation

**Why proper torque matters**:
- Loose connections cause hotspots & fires
- Over-tightening damages components
- Documentation proves proper installation

**What to record**:
- Bolt ID/location
- Target torque (Nm)
- Actual measured torque
- Technician initials

**Client signature** = quality assurance & warranty protection

---

<!-- 
# Slide 27
Facilitator Note:
- Perform a mini safety briefing as demonstration
- Show role cards and have volunteers act out roles
- Emphasize Stop-Work Authority: anyone can halt for safety
- Explain that tomorrow they will practice this in teams
-->

# Crew Safety Briefing

**2-minute safety talk before every installation**:
1. Assign roles (installer, spotter, tool handler)
2. Review safety equipment requirements
3. Identify emergency procedures
4. Establish communication signals

**Key safety principle**: 
"Stop-Work Authority" - Anyone can pause work if they see a safety concern

**Example**: "Check harnesses, wear gloves for panel handling, communicate before moving panels"

---

<!-- 
# Slide 28
Facilitator Note:
- This begins Day 5 content on commissioning
- Show actual commissioning checklist
- Explain each step and its purpose
- Connect to tomorrow's practical commissioning activity
-->

# Commissioning Process: Verifying Performance

**Key commissioning steps**:
1. Visual inspection of all components
2. String Voc measurement (≈40V × panel count)
3. Insulation resistance test (>1MΩ)
4. Inverter parameter setting
5. IV curve verification
6. 15-minute "soak test" at full power
7. System documentation & client training

**Goal**: Verify system meets design specifications

---

<!-- 
# Slide 29
Facilitator Note:
- Explain the concept of the IV curve simply
- Show example curve and point out the "knee" where power drops
- Demonstrate how shading moves the knee left
- If equipment available, show live trace on projector
-->

# IV Curve & Performance Testing

**IV Curve** = Current-Voltage relationship
- Shows panel/string performance
- "Knee" should be at ≥90% of STC
- Ideal test: clear day, 10am-2pm

**Common IV curve issues**:
- Shading: "knee" moves left (60% of normal)
- Poor connections: jagged curve
- Cell damage: multiple steps in curve

**Soak Test**: Run system 15+ minutes, verify no component overheating

---

<!-- 
# Slide 30
Facilitator Note:
- Display photos of common faults/problems
- Ask the group to identify what's wrong in each
- Explain symptoms and troubleshooting approach for each
- Connect to this afternoon's fault-finding exercise
-->

# Troubleshooting: Common System Faults

**Electrical Issues**:
- Reversed polarity: **negative** Voc reading
- Loose MC4: intermittent performance
- Blown fuse: zero continuity
- Wrong inverter settings: error codes

**Physical Issues**:
- Hotspots: visible with thermal camera
- Water ingress: corrosion at connections
- Shading: cell discoloration, hot cells
- Mounting movement: loose racking

---

<!-- 
# Slide 31
Facilitator Note:
- This begins Day 6 content on business aspects
- Explain net-metering concept simply with diagram
- Update on current policy status in Iraq
- Emphasize this affects system design choices
-->

# Grid Integration: Net-Metering & Billing

**Net-Metering Status in Iraq**:
- Ministry draft policy (2024): 1-for-1 kWh credit
- System size limit: 5kW residential
- Pilot program: University of Mosul

**Net-Billing Alternative**:
- Sell excess at **70 IQD/kWh**
- Purchase at standard rate

**Documentation required**:
- Application through Electricity Directorate
- System specification sheet
- Grid-compliant inverter certificate

---

<!-- 
# Slide 32
Facilitator Note:
- Present simple service packages that technicians can offer
- Explain why these make business sense in Iraq
- Show dust accumulation photo if available
- Connect to business plan activity later today
-->

# Service & Maintenance: Business Opportunities

**Profitable service offerings**:

1. **Annual Cleaning Package**:
   - Dust reduces output up to 6%
   - One cleaning = +4% output
   - Charge: 60,000 IQD/visit

2. **Battery Health Check**:
   - State of Health (SOH) testing
   - Early problem detection
   - Charge: 20,000 IQD/visit

3. **System Monitoring Setup**:
   - Wi-Fi dongle installation
   - Mobile app configuration
   - Charge: 85,000 IQD (one-time)

**Key**: Cash payment, stamped receipt

---

<!-- 
# Slide 33
Facilitator Note:
- Draw simple cash-flow timeline on board
- Walk through example: 4.6M IQD system → 1M IQD profit
- Emphasize deposit requirement to protect cash flow
- Connect to capstone project they'll complete today
-->

# Business Finance: Managing Cash Flow

**Solar business cash flow cycle**:
- Upfront costs: equipment, labor, permits
- Revenue timeline: deposit → progress → final

**Profitable pricing structure**:
- 30% deposit (covers equipment)
- Target margin: **22%**
- Payment schedule in contract

**Example**:
4.6M IQD total job cost → 1M IQD profit 
(after materials, labor, overhead)

---

<!-- 
# Slide 34
Facilitator Note:
- Explain the capstone project requirements
- Show sample completed portfolio with QR code
- Walk through the 10-page structure they should follow
- Form teams and assign roles for the capstone activity
-->

# Capstone Project & Professional Portfolio

**Final project requirements**:
- Complete 10-page solar design PDF
- Include site analysis, system design, financial analysis
- Address real-world constraints
- Present to client (role-play)

**Digital portfolio elements**:
- System design specifications
- Commissioning documentation
- Financial analysis
- QR code linking to complete work

**Goal**: Demonstrate job-ready skills

---

Your Markdown itself is **perfect**—every slide is correctly separated by a blank-line-plus-`---`, and the YAML front-matter is fine.  
What’s tripping you up is **how you’re exporting / previewing, not how you’re writing**.

---

### Why you only see the first slide

* **PNG / JPEG export (or the VS Code command “Export slide deck → Image”)**  
  Under the hood Marp calls the CLI with `--image` (or you ran something like  
  `marp slides.md -o cover.png`).  
  `--image` is *deliberately* designed to capture a **single title slide** for Open-Graph / social-card images citeturn0search6turn4view0

* **What you actually want**  
  * **All slides as a PDF or PPTX**:  
    ```bash
    marp slides.md --pdf      # PDF
    marp slides.md --pptx     # PowerPoint
    ```
  * **All slides as individual PNG/JPEG files**:  
    ```bash
    marp slides.md --images png   # or jpeg
    ```
    The `--images` flag tells Marp to render *every* page, not just the first citeturn4view0
  * **Live preview in VS Code**: open the Markdown, press <kbd>⌘/Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>K</kbd> then <kbd>P</kbd> (or click the Marp cat icon) and use the arrow keys / Pg-Down to move through the deck.

---

### Quick checklist

| Check | Fix |
|-------|-----|
| Exported filename ends in `.png` / `.jpg` but you expected multiple pages | Use `--images`, `--pdf`, or `--pptx` instead |
| VS Code shows only slide 1 in the side-by-side preview | Click inside the preview and use ← / → or Pg-Down |
| CLI command contains `--image` | Replace with `--images` |

Once you export with `--images`, `--pdf`, or `--pptx`, every slide (Slide 1 → Slide 34) will be included exactly as you’ve written them. Happy presenting, Bilal!
